Hi Sharon,

Thanks so much for the =
info and pics from your experiments! It seems I had read somewhere that whe=
n a camera is a true full spectrum that the visible light may wash out anyt=
hing seemn in the UV or IR range. Since most of my ghost hunts tend to be r=
estricted to daytime, the Moditronics full (duo) spectrum seems like the be=

I do want a Spectercam 3 as well. I guess I'=

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, leongbabe@... w=
rote:
>
> 
> Hi Draiga, Ursula, CB, and Rick, and all others interested in =
this topic:
> 
> As promised, I've attached a jpeg with the results of my c=
amera experiment using 1) digital point n' shoot camera, 2) Moditronics Dee=
p IR camera, 3) Moditronics Full ( "Duo") Spectrum camera, and 4) a Nikon c=
amera converted into a Full Spectrum camera. I took these shots, one after =
the other, and from the same angle, in a purportedly haunted alley in San F=
rancisco's Chinatown. Please note that I took these photos during the day, =
which was one of the reasons I purchased the two Moditronics cameras - thei=
r cameras don't see into the visible spectrum and thus prevent against visi=
ble light washing out any possible images that may be lurking in the IR and=
 UV spectrums. And, as you can see from the attached jpeg, in the fire esca=
pe one can see what looks like a head floating in the two photos I took wit=
h Moditronics Duo Spectrum and Deep IR cameras. In the two photos taken wit=
h the regular point n' shoot camera and the full spectrum camera, you can't=
 see the
 floating head at all because the visible light washed it out. Aga=
in, for night time investigations, the drawback with the Moditronics camera=
s is that you will need some kind of external light source in order to see =
anything (or, you can always turn on some lights - if lights are available,=
 why sit in the dark?)
> 
> Ursula, don't get me wrong, I think the Specter=
Cam 3 is a wonderful full spectrum camera (as a matter of fact, I've just p=
urchased one as a present to myself!). I'm going to experiment with it and =
will probably buy a filter for it that will block some of the visible light=
 because, again, I don't want visible light possibly washing out the IR and=
 UV spectrums, especially if I investigate during the day (I also investiga=
te a lot of battlefields and many battlefields close early).
> 
> Apologies=
 to the rest of you who may be asking, what does this have to do with EVPs?=
 Well, photos of true anomalies can help substantiate any EVPs captured and=
, I might add here, the Moditronics camcorders also record sound (unlike DV=
R cameras, such as Spectercams, where you would need to have a separate aud=
io recorder if you want sound to go with the images). And yes, I have also =
picked up EVPs on my camcorders. 
> 
> Finally, CB, I agree with you, the S=
VP cameras that Moditronics use for their conversions are pretty flimsy in =
construction (plastic casing). I've accidentally banged my Deep IR camera a=
gainst the gear shift in the car and (Sob!) the bottom of the camera broke =
off from the tripod. I duck-taped it back together and it still works, thou=
gh (whew!). (And yes, I, too, have noticed that the Ghost Hunters used the =
Moditronics full spectrum camera on one of their shows this year.)
> 
> The=
refore, Rick, don't sweat it. For what you get for the price, I think you d=
id fine. But like CB said, don't drop these cameras or bang them around too=
 much.
> 
> Lastly, I think all kinds and grades of cameras are worth exper=
imenting with. I've even captured a very interesting light anomaly with a c=
heap throwaway camera and have seen what appeared to be an apparition taken=
 with a point n' shoot. So, whatever one can afford, go with it!
> 
> Happy=
 Holidays Everyone!
> 
> Sharon from SF
>
